The bill would make abortions illegal from conception, and allows Oklahomans to sue abortion providers. (KOKH)OKLAHOMA CITY, Okla. (KOKH) — The most restrictive abortion ban in the state is expected to pass through the legislature this week.The bill would make abortions illegal from conception, and allows Oklahomans to sue abortion providers.There’s already been a few abortion bans signed into law this session, but lawmakers against the bill said this could be the most extreme ban.While the current law bans abortion after six weeks, this would prevent abortions from the moment an egg is fertilized.“It outlaws all abortions at any time, and also provides the so called bounty-hunter provision, which allows anyone and everyone to take these matters into their own hands and enforce this law,” Democratic Minority Leader, Rep. Emily Virgin said.RELATED | Gov. Stitt says women have other options besides abortionWhile Democrats against the bill think this will encourage vigilante lawsuits, Rep. Wendi Stearman, the sponsor of the bill, said that shouldn’t be a concern.“There should be no bounty hunting because we have laws on the books already for stalking and spying,” Rep. Stearman, (R)- Collinsville said. “So that shouldn’t be an issue.”The language specifically allows for contraceptives and Plan B, or the morning after pill.What it doesn’t doesn’t mention though is in vitro fertilization.By preventing abortions from the time of fertilization, Rep. Emily Virgin said this could impact women hoping to start a family with IVF.RELATED | Governor 'optimistic' on Project Ocean and his attempts to land big company“Looking at the language, it’s hard to see how it wouldn’t affect in vitro fertilization because it talks about as soon as the ovum and the sperm meet, and the egg is fertilized, that that means that’s a person,” Rep. Virgin said. “That’s what happens with in vitro fertilization, you create embryos.”Rep. Stearman said that is not addressed or included in the bill.“This would be in the case of proving that an abortion has occurred,” Rep. Stearman said. “And that would be tough to do in that situation.”Sources inside the Capitol said the bill will be heard Thursday.If it passes, it will head to the Governor’s desk.There’s an emergency clause on the bill, so it will go into affect with the Governor’s signature.For more local news delivered straight to your inbox sign up for our daily newsletter by clicking here.
